g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Strategy (=policy) Change the used strategy of an object, by ...
g.text: Strategy (=policy)Change the used strategy of an object, by defining a family of algorithms and making them interchangeable.

g.title: Rectangle.119
g.desc: (1) Differentiate the algorithm that an object uses during ru...
g.text: (1) Differentiate the algorithm that an object uses during runtime

g.title: Folded Corner.196
g.desc: The Strategy pattern entails both the negative and positive a...

g.text: The Strategy pattern entails both the negative and positive aspects of the Open Closed principle. All aspects are compared against situating the Strategy logic within the Context. The abstraction between Context and Strategies contribute to an additional form of indirection. The indirection makes the code more complicated because of decreasing navigability and debuggability. The applicability of the Strategy pattern should be chosen in case the Context changes frequently or is likely to change frequently.

g.title: Folded Corner.235
g.desc: The Strategy design pattern enables the clients to inject dif...

g.text: The Strategy design pattern enables the clients to inject different algorithms (=Strategies) into the Context during runtime. Each Strategy contains its own algorithm. These Strategies have some commonality, that is reflected via a common interface. The Strategy interface is used by the Context, which enables the possibility to pass the Strategies (via Polymorphism). The Context contains some generic logic that applies to all the Strategies. The Runtime flexibility can also be achieved by injecting an Enum into the Context. The Context varies the Strategy based on the defined enum. This approach hardwires the strategies to the Context, causing the Context to change when introducing a new Strategy.

g.title: Folded Corner.258
g.desc: The Strategy pattern compliments the Open Closed principle by...

g.text: The Strategy pattern compliments the Open Closed principle by enabling support of new Strategies without having to change the Context. This ensures stability of the production and test code. Stability, because an extension of the code base, by introducing a new Strategy, does not require the production nor test code (Context) to change. In contrast, having the Strategies situated within the Context and switching them via a conditional structure requires the Context to change when extension is required. The conditional structure should be extended with a new conditional that may break the stable code and/or test cases attached to the Context.

g.title: Folded Corner.276
g.desc: The Strategy pattern compliments the Single Responsibility pr...

g.text: The Strategy pattern compliments the Single Responsibility principle by extracting algorithmic logic into separate classes. This ensures reusability, readability, stability and testability. All aspects are compared against situating the Strategy logic within the Context. Reusability, because the algorithmic logic (Strategy) has been extracted from the Context. This means other Contexts can reuse the same strategies, without being dependent on a Context object directly. This enforces the Interface Segregation Principle. The testability improves, because the mocked interface of the Strategy is more focused then the Context. Also changes in the interface of Context X do not reflect on Context Y. This reduces recompilation and improves stability of the code base. Readability, the fine details of the algorithms are extracted from the core logic of the Context. This ensures readability in the Context. Additionally, as stated in the ‘When? (4)’ section, the cyclomatic complexity of the Context shrinks. This is because conditional structures are or ‘moved’ to the client (in case of a single client) or are completely disposed (in case of multiple clients). Stability, the separation of the Strategies from the Context localizes the impact of change. This means if change is required in one of the strategies, the change will not impact the context nor other Strategies. This has positive impact on both the test and production code. Additionally, merge conflicts between developers will decrease, because Strategy and Context logic are separated. Testability, because instead of having the Strategies encapsulated within the Context and called via a high cyclomatic function, they can now be tested individually. This shrinks the problem window enabling bringing the code faster under test and pinpointing out failures more easily.

g.title: Rectangle.281
g.desc: (2) The object must support an open-end of algorithms and cha...
g.text: (2) The object must support an open-end of algorithms and changes frequently

g.title: Rectangle.283
g.desc: (3) Classes only differ in the algorithm they use
g.text: (3) Classes only differ in the algorithm they use

g.title: Folded Corner.285
g.desc: The Strategy design pattern enables the possibility to add ne...

g.text: The Strategy design pattern enables the possibility to add new Strategies without modifying the given Context. The pattern overcomes that a class (=Context) has multiple algorithms (=Strategies) hard wired. ‘Hard wiring’ will cause continuous change of the class, when it is priorly unknown how many algorithms it will need to support. Another indication could be that the class often changes (an indication based on experience). The pattern might not be suitable in case the algorithms, that the object needs to support, do not frequently or never change.

g.title: Folded Corner.292
g.desc: The Strategy design pattern is useful when multiple classes o...

g.text: The Strategy design pattern is useful when multiple classes only differ in the behavior or algorithmic logic they perform. The algorithms can be extracted from the given classes and ‘listed’ under a common interface. This opens up the possibility to get rid of code duplication and use a single class (Context) that can work with different algorithms (Strategies). This means the diversity first accomplished on the class level is now resolved on the object level. A indication, for the Strategy to be applicable, is code duplication. This duplication can be resolved in different ways, for example by using inheritance. However, inheritance hardwires the Context and the Strategies. This might not be desirable incase the Strategies must be re-used by a complete different context. Not intertwining Context and Strategy dimensions, ensures that possible other contexts are not dependent on functionality they don’t use.

g.title: Folded Corner.297
g.desc: The Strategy design pattern decomposes conditional structures...

g.text: The Strategy design pattern decomposes conditional structures in a given class (Context). A Context, having multiple different clients, provides slightly modified versions of its logic via conditionals. The clients pass the Context an argument (e.g. Enum) to make know which variant of the Context logic they want to work with. The cyclomatic complexity of the Context grows linearly with the new clients that require a slightly modified version of the Context logic. Each time the Context needs change, risks the stability of the test and production code. The Strategy pattern proposes to decompose the conditional structure in standalone objects, that can be injected in the Context. This means that different clients construct a Strategy and provide it to the Context. This way the conditional structure of the Context can be removed or reduced. To note: applying the Strategy pattern in case the same client requires multiple variants of the Context will result in shifting the conditional structure to the client. However, moving the conditional structure from Context to client can be a tradeoff that is desirable or not. Additionally, encapsulating strategies in separate objects offers additional selection mechanisms (e.g. hashmaps).

g.title: Folded Corner.308
g.desc: The Strategy pattern entails both the negative and positive a...

g.text: The Strategy pattern entails both the negative and positive aspects of the Single Responsibility principle. All aspects are compared against situating the Strategy logic within the Context. The introduction of a separate class for each Strategy adds to the indirection factor of the code. The logic is not situated in the Context anymore, but is now referenced by a separate object. This has negative impact on the readability/understandability of the code, because the logic is more scattered. It becomes harder to comprehend the Context and Strategies as a ‘whole’. The Cyclomatic complexity that the Strategy reduces in the Context could move to the respective Client. This means the overall complexity of the code base is not reduced, but moved! This statement is not correct in case multiple clients all dependent on a different Strategy context combination.
